key_title: Key to the genera of Rubiaceae

breadcrumbs.key_title: Key to the main groups of plants in Victoria
Key to the families of Dicotyledons

source.author: Thompson, I.R.
source.title: A revision of Asperula and Galium (Rubieae: Rubiaceae) in Australia
source.citation: From: Thompson, I.R. (2009). A revision of Asperula and Galium (Rubieae: Rubiaceae) in Australia. Muelleria 27:36-112.

leads.lead_text: Leaves (at least on lower stems) apparently in whorls of 3–12 (but some components of the whorls are leaf-like stipules sometimes slightly smaller than the true leaves); stigmas capitate
Leaves opposite throughout, with stipules much smaller than leaves, free or fused in a sheath; stigmas filiform, rarely capitate
Flowers bright pink or purplish, sessile, in terminal involucrate heads; calyx con- spicuous, 6-lobed

Flowers white or yellow (rarely tinged pink or reddish), in terminal or axillary cymes (sometimes reduced to a single flower), sometimes congested, but flowers pedicellate; calyx absent or if present then not lobed
[link through]
Corolla funnel-shaped, tube distinct; inflorescences often terminal; fruit fleshy, 2-lobed, indehiscent
Corolla rotate, tube very short; inflorescences usually axillary; fruit dry, breaking into 2 mericarps
Flowers in heads or clusters; fruits often compound, formed from several united ovaries
Flowers not united in heads or clusters; fruits never compound
Stipules bearing several stiff bristles along margin; fruits not compound, each consisting of four 1-seeded mericarps
Stipules entire or with 1 or 2 teeth, but not with obvious marginal bristles; fruits compound from fusion of ovaries
[link through]
Compound fruit fleshy; stipules deciduous; woody climber of East Gippsland
Compound fruit dry, capsular; stipules persistent; herbs or subshrubs
[link through]
Inflorescences c. spherical or hemispherical; compound fruit dehiscing by many irregularly shaped lids; widespread, often diffuse malodorous herbs

Inflorescences apparently umbellate with few to many connate part-inflorescences; compound fruit dehiscing by a single round lid; rounded to erect subshrub usually of dry rocky areas in east, Brisbane Ranges and Castlemaine areas
[link through]
Annual herb with a woody taproot; fruit a loculicidal capsule; stigma capitate
Erect woody shrub or prostrate subshrub or herb, rooting at nodes; fruit indehiscent; stigma filiform
[link through]
Plant usually a woody shrub or subshrub (sometimes prostrate and rooting at nodes) or tree; flowers unisexual and plants dioecious; fruit a fleshy drupe; calyx (at least of female flowers) 4-lobed
Plant herbaceous, prostrate, rooting at nodes; flowers bisexual; fruit fleshy or dry; calyx 2-lobed or truncate
Calyx-lobes well-developed; fruit a dry leathery drupe
Calyx-lobes absent or rudimentary; fruit a soft fleshy drupe
[link through]
[link through]
